notes.front: What is the default route preference for OSPF internal?
notes.front_reverse: What protocol has the default route preference of 10?

notes.front: What is the default routing table name for IPv4 unicast routes?
notes.front_reverse: What kind of routes does the inet.0 routing table contain?

notes.front: What is the default routing table name for IPv6 unicast routes?
notes.front_reverse: What kind of routes does the inet6.0 routing table contain?

notes.front: T/F: You can commit a configuration to a factory-default Juniper device with the default hostname.
notes.front_reverse: T/F: A hostname is required to commit a configuration to a factory-default Juniper device.

notes.front: What configuration statement do you NEED to be able to commit a configuration to a factory-default Juniper device?
notes.front_reverse: T/F: You cannot commit your first configuration to a factory-default Juniper device without a root user password.

notes.front: What command can you use to view the briefest output of the operational status of all interfaces on a Juniper device?
notes.front_reverse: What information does the command "show interfaces terse" show?
notes.back_reverse: Brief information about all of the interfaces/logical units on the device and their operational status(es)

notes.front: You have just issued a commit and-quit at the configuration mode prompt. What do you need to do to make your config changes persist at reboot?
notes.front_reverse: T/F: You don't need to do anything after committing your configuration to have those changes persist at the next reboot.

notes.front: What is the default password to the root account on a factory-default Juniper device?
notes.front_reverse: T/F: If you type root and hit Enter, you are immediately logged in to a Junos device running default configuration.
